newsitem.title: GERMANY: Jittery German stocks seen calming - dealers.
newsitem.headline: Jittery German stocks seen calming - dealers.

text.p: The German stock market is likely to calm before the weekend after a series of shocks took the DAX index down about two percent this week, dealers said on Thursday.

Dealers said the impact of Tuesday's suprising profit warning by software group SAP AG, which triggered a 23 percent slide in the stock, had begun to wane by Thursday afternoon and that the outlook was for a slow recovery.
The 30-share IBIS DAX index was up 5.64 points at 2,684.53 in mid-afternoon dealings, six points ahead of the floor session close at 2,678.43.

"The main point for me is that there has been no real selling pressure. People have been offloading, but it's been mainly profit-taking," said one Munich dealer, who said he saw the DAX supported around the 2,650-point level.
The Bundesbank's decision to leave rates unchanged came as no surprise to the market and should not create any lasting pressure, dealers added.

Attention was likely to be focused on the banking sector, now into its nine-months earnings season following a report from Deutsche Bank AG on Thursday morning, which had helped it outperform through the day.
